Description: The SEC sanctioned five India-based affiliates of PricewaterhouseCoopers that formerly served as independent auditors of Satyam Computer Services Limited for repeatedly conducting deficient audits of the company's financial statements and enabling a massive accounting fraud to go undetected for several years.

IBM Corporation and PriceWaterhouseCoopers agreed to pay the United States a total of more than $5.2 million to settle allegations that the companies solicited and provided improper payments and other things of value on technology contracts with government agencies.
PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP agreed to pay $2.4 million to settle allegations that it aided reporting violations by The Warnaco Group.

PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP agreed to pay $1 million to settle allegations of improper professional conduct in connection with its audit of SmarTalk TeleServices, Inc.'s year-end 1997 financial statements.

PriceWaterhouseCoopers, LLP (PWC) agreed to pay $41.9 million to settle allegations that it made false claims to the United States in connection with claims it made to federal agencies for travel reimbursement. PWC received rebates on its travel expenses from travel and credit card companies, airlines, hotels, rental car agencies, and travel service providers.
PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP and its broker-dealer affiliate PricewaterhouseCoopers Securities LLC agreed to pay $5 million to settled alleged violations of auditor independence rules.

Private Litigation Case Title: Kress et al v. PriceWaterhouse Coopers, LLP

Description: PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP paid the state a total of $5.85 million to resolve allegations of alleged fraud and accounting improprieties at Tyco International Ltd.

PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP agreed to pay $7.9 million to settle allegations of improper professional conduct in connection with 19 engagements on behalf of 15 SEC-registered issuers and violating auditor independence rules in connection with engagements for one issuer where the firm performed prohibited non-audit services.

Company: PricewaterhouseCoopers Zhong Tian CPAs Limited Company
Description: The Securities and Exchange Commission imposed sanctions against four China-based accounting firms that had refused to turn over documents related to investigations of potential fraud.

The Department of Financial Services announced that PricewaterhouseCoopers' Regulatory Advisory Services business would be suspended for 24 months from accepting consulting engagements at financial institutions regulated by the DFS), make a $25 million payment to the State of New York, and implement a series of reforms after improperly altering a report submitted to regulators regarding sanctions and anti-money laundering compliance at Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Private Litigation Case Title: Rabin et al v. Pricewaterhousecoopers LLP
